Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: Inexperienced staff are about to run a hazardous batch without understanding safety protocols.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Story: I was tightening the last bolt on the conveyor when I overheard the new staff discussing the next batch. Their voices were uncertain, and I realized they hadn’t reviewed the safety protocols. As the machine repairer, it was my duty to guide them, to make sure no one got hurt. I could see the confusion in their eyes, the way they looked to me for reassurance. Just then, my phone buzzed. It was Miriam from the synagogue. Her father had passed away, and the family needed me to officiate the funeral—immediately, if possible. As their rabbi, I was expected to be there, to offer comfort and lead the service. My heart twisted. The staff needed my expertise to prevent a possible disaster, but the grieving family needed my presence and compassion. Both roles demanded my full attention, both were urgent, and I stood there, torn, feeling the weight of two worlds pressing in on me.
